		<title>nwordl-logo-gray</title>

		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Feb 2015 03:01:16 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>Photo restoration</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?attachment_id=392</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Feb 2015 06:57:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/photo-restoration.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>392</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-02-13 01:57:52]]></wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[attachment]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url><![CDATA[http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/photo-restoration.jpg]]></wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_attached_file]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2015/02/photo-restoration.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_attachment_metadata]]></wp:meta_key>

		<title>First Sunset</title>

		<pubDate>Sat, 14 Feb 2015 06:55:37 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>Citrix Project Accelerator</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/projects/citrix-project-accelerator/thumb_pa/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 22 Aug 2016 20:20:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/thumb_PA.png</guid>

		<title>Project Serenity</title>

		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>About Me</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/about/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Dec 2007 15:14:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/about/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="contentRow aboutMe"><img class="whiteBorderPhoto alignleft size-full wp-image-570" src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/mommy-and-conrad.jpg" alt="Natasha and her son Conrad" width="284" height="368" />
<div class="contentColumn">
<h3>Passionate UI Developer/Designer</h3>
I take pride in my work and am very passionate about coding and designing. I'm detail-oriented and a problem solver. My motto is "if there's a way, I'll find it". I make every effort to always complete my tasks, and to do so in the most efficient and creative ways possible. I also aim to produce clean and cross-browser compliant code. Having a Bachelors degree in Graphic Design and years of shadowing some of the best UX Designers are additional skills that I bring to the table. All of these experiences have taught me to design and code from a place of empathy for both clients and users.

<h3>Life Outside of Coding</h3>
When I'm not working, you'll find me either spending time with my son Conrad, learning about or discussing the benefits of good nutrition, singing or listening to music and/or discussing various topics such as spirituality, relationships and everything in between. If you're interested in learning more, be sure to check out my <a href="http://www.natashapierrelouis.com" target="_blank">blog</a>.

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

		<title>Thank you for Your Donation</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/thank-you-for-your-donation/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 30 Dec 2007 01:18:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<h2>Thank you!</h2>
Your kind donation has been graciously accepted. Thank you so very much, and may the same level of generosity be extended to you.

Always,
Natasha]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Birthday Wishes and Quick Updates</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=56</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=56</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm still working on my "energy crisis" but I think I am making great progress. I realized that I have a strange food addiction. It's not the type where I can't stop eating, though there have been times when I've gone overboard. Rather, it's the type of addiction where I'm always thinking about food. I'll be eating breakfast and wondering what I'm going to have for lunch or eating lunch and wondering about dinner. Unless I'm completely busy, I think about food so much that I end up eating, even when I'm not hungry.

I think that the only reason I'm not morbidly obese is because I have muscle mass under the layers of fat from years of carrying heavy bags and lifting mom. In addition, most of the foods that I gravitate towards are healthy (except for the occasional cake - which I haven't had in a while, veggie tempura -  which I had last night  and home made potato chips served at my workplace's cafeteria). I've been striving towards vegetarian/raw vegan lifestyle and have been eating lots of fruits, green smoothies and veggies. As I' m writing this, It dawns on me that I have started to see this as an observer... I guess " A New Earth" by Eckhart Tolle is starting to kick in after all.

Speaking of A New Earth, my birthday is coming up. This is a momentous occasion and an opportunity for you to take a tax write-off. To make it easier on you, I am going to tell you exactly what I would like to have this year. See how thoughtful I am. ;)

Birthday Wishlist:

Mac Book Pro

Specifications
<ul>
	<li>2.6GHz Intel Core 2 Duo</li>
	<li>SuperDrive 8x (DVD±R DL/DVD±RW/CD-RW)</li>
	<li>Accessory Kit</li>
	<li>4GB 667MHz DDR2 SDRAM - 2x2GB</li>
	<li>200GB Serial ATA Drive @ 7200 rpm</li>
	<li>MacBook Pro 17-inch Hi-Resolution LED Widescreen Display</li>
	<li>Apple USB Modem</li>
	<li>Apple MagSafe Airline Adapter</li>
	<li>Apple Remote</li>
	<li>Final Cut Express preinstalled</li>
	<li>Logic Express preinstalled</li>
	<li>Backlit Keyboard (English) / User's Guide</li>
	<li>AppleCare Protection Plan for MacBook Pro (w/or w/o Display) - Auto-enroll</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

</a></section><section class="skillsArea">
<h3 class="widget-title"><span class="wow bounce animated" style="visibility: visible; animation-name: bounce;">Skills</span></h3>
I've been designing and developing websites for over 10 years. I have strong HTML and CSS skills, and am very comfortable with JavaScript, Java, PHP and .NET. I've worked using agile methodologies for over 5 years and became a Certified ScrumMaster in 2012. I'm a very fast learner. Put any project in front of me, regardless of the programming language, and in a very short time I'll figure out how to complete my task.

I also have Bachelors degree in Graphic Design. Although I've worked more as a developer than a designer, my years of studying the fundamentals of design helps me to be very detail-oriented and to develop from a creative perspective. In addition, I've had the opportunity to shadow some amazing UX Architects and have learned a lot from them about human-centered design. This helps me to code from a place of empathy for both my clients and the end-users.

Front-End Development 90% UI/Graphic Design 80% Design Thinking 80% Agile Development 85% Wireframe 75% Painting 75% <script>
function sbar(){
jQuery(".skillbar").each(function(){
jQuery(this).find(".skillbar-bar").animate({
width:jQuery(this).attr("data-percent")
},3000);
});	
}
if ( jQuery("#skillbar_straight").next().is(":appeared") ){
sbar();
} else {
jQuery( window ).scroll(function() {
if ( jQuery("#skillbar_straight").next().is(":appeared") ){
sbar();
}
});
}
</script><a class="all-news" title="View my resume" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/resume/#page">View my resume</a>

</section><section id="testimonials" class="testimonials-area">
<h3 class="widget-title"><span class="wow bounce">Testimonials</span></h3>
I have known and worked closely with Natasha for several years now and it’s always been a pleasure to work with her. Her work is of the highest caliber and she always gets it done on time. Many’s the time I’ve seen her work long and late hours into the night to make a deadline. She was respected and liked by all her co-workers. I hope to have the pleasure of working with her again.
<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Dr. Tim Murphrey</h4>
<span class="client-function col-md-8">Senior Manager@Citrix</span>Natasha is a very talented and creative front-end designer. I saw her true passion for web design and user experience while working with her at Citrix. Natasha is very hardworking and has great web technology skills with an eye for detail. She makes her design look perfect before even it goes to internal demo and she has created many beautiful applications at Citrix. It was pleasure working with Natasha, she would be great addition to any team.
<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Dhwani Shah</h4>
<span class="client-function col-md-8">Web Producer@Citrix</span>Natasha possesses great skills in both User Interface Design and Development with extensive knowledge in User Experience best practices and methodology. I have worked with Natasha in many projects and I have always observed a great attention to detail and creativity in everything she does. Her positive attitude is contagious. She is creative, knowledgeable and always eager to learn and improve her skills. Natasha has always conducted herself in a professional and business-like manner. It has been a pleasure working with Natasha and I highly recommend her.
<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Ana Diez</h4>
<span class="client-function col-md-8">User Experience Designer@Citrix and Author</span>Natasha is truly a well-rounded developer. I worked with her for many years and during that time I have seen her tackle problems in all aspects of the application. She is adequately capable of diving into the backend of the application as well as the front end. However, Natasha’s best quality is in the dedication and attention to detail, allowing her to create beautiful, professional looking designs in all of the web applications she was involved in.

I believe she is a very strong developer, an excellent team player, and a valuable asset to any team.
<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Luis Atencio</h4>
<span class="client-function col-md-8">Staff Software Engineer@Citrix</span> <a class="all-news" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/testimonials-recommendation/#page"> View more testimonials and recommendations </a></section><section id="social" class="social-area">

<h3 class="widget-title"><span class="wow bounce animated" style="visibility: visible; animation-name: bounce;">Skills</span></h3>

<div class="contentColumn skillsDescription">
<p>I've been designing and developing websites for over 10 years. I have strong HTML and CSS skills, and am very comfortable with JavaScript, Java, PHP and .NET. I've worked using agile methodologies for over 5 years and became a Certified ScrumMaster in 2012.  I'm a very fast learner. In addition, I've had the opportunity to shadow some amazing UX Architects and have learned a lot from them about human-centered design. This helps me to code from a place of empathy for both my clients and the end-users.</p>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_panels_data_preview]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:3:{s:7:"widgets";a:4:{i:0;a:7:{s:5:"title";s:11:"Recent Work";s:8:"category";s:15:"web-development";s:9:"image_uri";s:0:"";s:6:"number";s:1:"6";s:7:"see_all";s:48:"http://natashasworld.com/journal/portfolio/#page";s:12:"see_all_text";s:14:"View Portfolio";s:11:"panels_info";a:6:{s:5:"class";s:15:"Moesia_Projects";s:4:"grid";i:0;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:0;s:9:"widget_id";s:36:"93dba8f6-b276-4321-99e4-c32f703ea1d8";s:5:"style";a:2:{s:27:"background_image_attachment";b:0;s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}i:1;a:4:{s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:2102:"<section class="skillsArea">
<div class="container">
<h3 class="widget-title"><span class="wow bounce animated" style="visibility: visible; animation-name: bounce;">Skills</span></h3>
<div class="contentRow skillsBar">
<div class="contentColumn skillsDescription">
<p>I've been designing and developing websites for over 10 years. I have strong HTML and CSS skills, and am very comfortable with JavaScript, Java, PHP and .NET. I've worked using agile methodologies for over 5 years and became a Certified ScrumMaster in 2012.  I'm a very fast learner. Put any project in front of me, regardless of the programming language, and in a very short time I'll figure out how to complete my task. </p>

<p>I also have Bachelors degree in Graphic Design. Although I've worked more as a developer than a designer, my years of studying the fundamentals of design helps me to be very detail-oriented and to develop from a creative perspective. In addition, I've had the opportunity to shadow some amazing UX Architects and have learned a lot from them about human-centered design. This helps me to code from a place of empathy for both my clients and the end-users.</p>
</div>
[skillwrapper type="bar"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="90" title="Front-End Development"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="80" title="UI/Graphic Design"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="80" title="Design Thinking"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="85" title="Agile Development"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="75" title=Wireframe Creation Experience"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="75" title="Painting"]
[/skillwrapper]
</div>
<p><a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/resume/#page" class="all-news" title="View my resume">View my resume</a></p>
</div>

							<img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/book-cover-350x250.jpg" class="attachment-project-image wp-post-image" alt="Book cover for A Journey of Clarity by Ana Diez" height="250" width="350">															<a class="link-icon" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/projects/book-cover-for-a-journey-of-clarity/" title="Book Cover for A Journey of Clarity – Print, Graphic Design"><i class="fa fa-link"></i></a>
																												<a class="pp-icon" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/book-cover.jpg" rel="prettyPhoto[pp_gallery]"><i class="fa fa-search"></i></a>
																				
						
					
																								
						
							<img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/magazine-spread2-350x250.jpg" class="attachment-project-image wp-post-image" alt="Dreads Magazine Spread 2" height="250" width="350">															<a class="link-icon" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/projects/dreads-magazine-spread-2/" title="Dreads Magazine Spread 2 – Print, Graphic Design"><i class="fa fa-link"></i></a>
																												<a class="pp-icon" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/magazine-spread2.jpg" rel="prettyPhoto[pp_gallery]"><i class="fa fa-search"></i></a>
																				
						
					
																								
						
							<img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/magazine-spread1-350x250.jpg" class="attachment-project-image wp-post-image" alt="Dreads magazine spread 1" height="250" width="350">															<a class="link-icon" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/projects/dreads-magazine-spread-1/" title="Dreads Magazine Spread 1 – Print, Graphic Design"><i class="fa fa-link"></i></a>

							<img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/magazine-cover-350x250.jpg" class="attachment-project-image wp-post-image" alt="Serenity magazine cover" height="250" width="350">															<a class="link-icon" href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/projects/serenity-magazine-cover/" title="Serenity Magazine Cover – Print, Graphic Design"><i class="fa fa-link"></i></a>

		</section>		
			<section id="social" class="social-area">

	<item>
		<title>Resume</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/resume/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Feb 2015 03:44:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/?page_id=525</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="resumePage">
<h2 class="workTitle">Natasha Pierre-Louis UI Designer &amp; Front-End Developer</h2>
A professional front-end developer with over 10 years of design and development experience with HTML and CSS. Other skills include responsive web design, wireframing and producing mockups within an agile environment (Certified ScrumMaster ’12). I have a Bachelor’s degree in Graphic Design and am very comfortable troubleshooting within JavaScript, Java, PHP and .NET. I have also learned a lot about user experience from some amazing UX Architects and am interested in pursuing a UI Designer/Front-End Developer position.

<a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Bx1o-w_qfznV6HJ_ON8tbQaYjxqfhN2Twrm3cRD0ScM/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">[wp-svg-icons icon="google-drive" wrap="span"] Download Resume from Google Drive</a>
<div class="contentRow skillsWrapper">
<h3>Skills</h3>
<div class="contentColumn">[skillwrapper type="bar"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="90" title="Front-End Development"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="80" title="UI/Graphic Design"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="80" title="Design Thinking"]
[/skillwrapper]</div>
<div class="contentColumn skills">[skillwrapper type="bar"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="85" title="Agile Development"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="75" title=Wireframe Creation Experience"]
[skill title_background="#214665" bar_foreground="#3b6b94" bar_background="#dddddd" percent="75" title="Painting"]
[/skillwrapper]</div>
</div>
<div class="contentRow experiencesWrapper">
<h3>Experience</h3>
<div class="contentRow experience">
<h4><strong>Uniform Advantage</strong> - Front End Developer 2, 04/2015 - Present</h4>
<ul>
 	<li>Develops cross-browser compatible, standards-compliant and responsive web pages using HTML5, CSS3, Bootstrap 3, Sass, JavaScript and template scripting, according to software requirements and design specifications</li>
 	<li>Debugs, maintains and updates applications within the .NET MVC framework</li>
 	<li>Keeps current with technical trends and incorporates them within assignments as appropriate</li>
 	<li>Leads the initiative to define the standards for UI/UX Development</li>
 	<li>Works closely with the Art and Marketing Team</li>
 	<li>Recommends improvements and changes in designs and gives professional appraisal on implementation of the design as planned and/or executed</li>
 	<li>Analyzes and contributes to project requirements and design specifications</li>
</ul>
<h4><strong>Citrix Systems</strong> - Senior Web Developer, 09/2010 - 02/2015</h4>
<ul>
 	<li>Developed cross-browser compatible, standards-compliant and responsive web pages using HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript and template scripting, according to software requirements and design specifications</li>
 	<li>Created the User Interface and Visual Designs for applications while focusing on user needs and optimal user experience</li>
 	<li>Worked closely with UX Designers and regularly attended UX Meetups in order to expand my knowledge of human-centered design</li>
 	<li>Debugged, maintained and updated applications within the Google Web Toolkit framework as well as Java-based templates such as Freemarker</li>
 	<li>Worked as the dedicated Front-end Developer for<a href="http://project.citrix.com/"> Citrix Project Accelerator</a> and <a href="https://www.citrix.com/products/xenapp-xendesktop/upgrade.html"> Citrix Project Serenity</a></li>
 	<li>Volunteered to help migrate<a href="http://akidsbraintumorcure.org/"> A Kids’ Brain Tumor Cure PLGA Foundation’s</a> site to WordPress</li>
 	<li>Kept current with technical trends and incorporated them within assignments as appropriate</li>
 	<li>Recommended improvements and changes in designs and gave professional appraisal on implementation of the design as planned and/or executed</li>
 	<li>Analyzed requirements, and contributed to software requirements and design specifications for projects of significant scope</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="contentRow experience">
<h4><strong>BGT Partners</strong> - UI Developer, 01/2010 - 09/2010</h4>
<ul>
 	<li>Developed cross-browser compatible and standards-compliant HTML/XHTML Pages based on Visual Designs provided by the Graphic Design team</li>
 	<li>Created reusable templates within PHP framework for client websites</li>
 	<li>Debugged and fixed layout issues within development team's .NET and JavaScript framework</li>
 	<li>Documented and maintained coding, commenting and validation</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="contentRow experience">
<h4><strong>Automated Healthcare Solutions</strong> - Multimedia Specialist, 01/2009 – 10/2009</h4>
<ul>
 	<li>Captured and edited videos with Final Cut Pro</li>
 	<li>Created Interactive DVDs with DVD Studio Pro</li>
 	<li>Created patent drawings</li>
 	<li>Created the User Interface and Visual Designs for web based applications</li>
 	<li>Developed and designed cross-browser pages within a .NET environment</li>
 	<li>Documented and maintained coding, commenting, validation and testing standards</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="contentRow experience">
<h4><strong>Kaplan University</strong> - HTML Developer/Designer, 12/2007 - 01/2009</h4>
<ul>
 	<li>Created Visual Designs for web pages based on UI Team prototypes</li>
 	<li>Developed and designed cross-browser pages for a .NET environment</li>
 	<li>Debugged and fixed layout issues within development team's ASP and JavaScript framework</li>
 	<li>Documented and maintained coding, commenting, validation and testing standards</li>
 	<li>Developed HTML Style Guides based on finalized templates</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="contentRow educationWrapper">
<h3>Education</h3>
<h4>Bachelor of Fine Arts, Graphic Design, December 2003</h4>
Florida Atlantic University, Davie, FL, GPA – 3.4
Design Against Fur Student Poster Competition, Honorable Mention, 2003
<h4 class="last-child">Associate of Science, Computer Graphics and Designs, April 1996</h4>
Keiser College, Fort Lauderdale, FL, GPA - 3.8

</div>

	<item>
		<title>Testimonials &amp; Recommendation</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/testimonials-recommendation/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Feb 2015 02:31:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/?page_id=561</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[		<section id="testimonials" class="testimonials-area">
			
				<h3 class="widget-title"><span class="wow bounce">What our clients say</span></h3>																			
						<p>I have known and worked closely with Natasha for several years now and it’s always been a pleasure to work with her. Her work is of the highest caliber and she always gets it done on time. Many’s the time I’ve seen her work long and late hours into the night to make a deadline. She was respected and liked by all her co-workers. I hope to have the pleasure of working with her again.</p>

												<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Dr. Tim Murphrey</h4>
													<span class="client-function col-md-8">Senior Manager@Citrix</span>
												
					
																			
						<p>Natasha is a very talented and creative front-end designer. I saw her true passion for web design and user experience while working with her at Citrix. Natasha is very hardworking and has great web technology skills with an eye for detail. She makes her design look perfect before even it goes to internal demo and she has created many beautiful applications at Citrix. It was pleasure working with Natasha, she would be great addition to any team.</p>

												<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Dhwani Shah</h4>
													<span class="client-function col-md-8">Web Producer@Citrix</span>
												
					
																			
						<p>Natasha possesses great skills in both User Interface Design and Development with extensive knowledge in User Experience best practices and methodology. I have worked with Natasha in many projects and I have always observed a great attention to detail and creativity in everything she does. Her positive attitude is contagious. She is creative, knowledgeable and always eager to learn and improve her skills. Natasha has always conducted herself in a professional and business-like manner. It has been a pleasure working with Natasha and I highly recommend her. </p>

												<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Ana Diez</h4>
													<span class="client-function col-md-8">User Experience Designer@Citrix and Author</span>
												
					
																			
						<p>Natasha is truly a well-rounded developer. I worked with her for many years and during that time I have seen her tackle problems in all aspects of the application. She is adequately capable of diving into the backend of the application as well as the front end. However, Natasha’s best quality is in the dedication and attention to detail, allowing her to create beautiful, professional looking designs in all of the web applications she was involved in.</p>
<p>I believe she is a very strong developer, an excellent team player, and a valuable asset to any team. </p>

												<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Luis Atencio</h4>
													<span class="client-function col-md-8">Staff Software Engineer@Citrix</span>
												
					
																			
						<p>Natasha is a first time mom who is loving, dedicated and protective of her son. She is an awesome mom !</p>

												<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Cris Brown</h4>
													<span class="client-function col-md-8">Nanny</span>
												
					
																			
						<p>I had the pleasure to work with Natasha at various projects at Citrix and was always impressed by her knowledge beyond the “front end” work. She helped me in many ways education clients so we do the right thing for the user. I should also mention that Natasha has also great design skills which makes her a very unique talent and extremely valuable to any company.</p>

												<h4 class="client-name col-md-8">Marta Guerra</h4>
													<span class="client-function col-md-8">UX Designer, Innovator@Citrix</span>
												
					
							
							<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/natashapl" class="all-news">
											View more recommendations on LinkedIn									</a>
					
						
		</section>

	<item>
		<title>Welcome to Natasha&#039;s World</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/22/welcome-to-natashas-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 22 Dec 2007 17:13:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/22/welcome-to-natashas-world/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hello everyone and welcome to Natasha's World! To start off, I want to wish all of you Happy Holidays. I've been wanting to have my blog up for a while, but the timing was never right. In case you haven't read my About page, I went through 9 layouts before I settled on this one. For a while there, I thought maybe it wasn't meant for me to have a blog anymore. Then about a week ago, right before I was to give up,  the idea for this layout came to me.  So a week later, I am writing my first blog post in years, and it feels good.

But as excited as I am, I want to confess that this site is not 100% complete. Here are a few tasks from my to-do list:
<ul>
	<li>Start posting video blogs</li>
	<li>Update my portfolio with more samples of my work and integrate it with the look and  feel of this site (still working on the details of that, but it should be interesting :) )</li>
	<li>Add a "Featured Natasha" section to this site, where I give props to fellow Natashas who have cool websites or who are doing cool things to better the world.</li>
</ul>
I have a few more ideas, but this is just to give you a sample of some of the things that I'm going to be working on over the next few weeks. Anyhow, I am very happy you stopped by and please stay tuned because i have more to come. 'Til next time. ;)]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>12</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2007-12-22 12:13:54]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2007-12-22 17:13:54]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[welcome-to-natashas-world]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="first-post"><![CDATA[first post]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="natashas-world"><![CDATA[Natasha's World]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="personal"><![CDATA[Personal]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="welcome"><![CDATA[welcome]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Second Life - What&#039;s it all about?</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/22/second-life-whats-it-all-about/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 22 Dec 2007 17:15:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/22/second-life-whats-it-all-about/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/sl_logo.jpg" title="Second Life"><img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/sl_logo.jpg" class="border_space" alt="Second Life" align="left" border="0" /></a>As I mentioned on my <a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/about/" title="About Natasha">About</a> page, I'm a proud member of <a href="http://www.secondlife.com/?u=0f7085f55f4e4ae1675d6ee9faffe78d" title="Second Life" target="_blank">SL (Second Life)</a>. I joined in December of 2005 and haven't looked back since. What makes SL cool is that it is about 98% user created. What this means is that your experience can be different each time you log in.  Now to be real, SL is not perfect... it was never meant to be. I've heard talk that many believe that theres is a risk of getting addicted to it, but um... isn't that the same risk with all Virtual Worlds? Like I told a buddy of mine recently, if people remember that SL is not a game, but another way to interact with people online, then I don't think addiction would be an issue.

Ok, now that I think about it, I can see how many can think that SL is addictive. Being that there is so much creative freedom and things to see, many who first join don't know where to begin. Should they learn to build? Should they go site seeing? Or what about the clubs or different events... so many to choose from! Oh and let's not forget the fact that you definitely want to look your best, so shop 'til you drop!

<a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/princess_new.jpg" title="Princess Pierterson"><img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/princess_new.jpg" alt="Princess Pierterson" class="border_space" align="left" border="0" /></a>Hmmm, ok I take it back, Second Life can be a bit addictive at first. So here's what I can do for  you: Once you <a href="http://www.secondlife.com/join/?u=0f7085f55f4e4ae1675d6ee9faffe78d" title="Join Second Life" target="_blank">sign up</a>, look for me inworld. My name in SL is Princess Pierterson. See that pretty girl in the pict to your left - that's how I currently look inworld. I own an art gallery there called "Princess' Original Art Gallery" that showcases some of my artwork and designs. I am also a Top Model with one of the premier Modeling Agencies in Second Life called <a href="http://www.aspiresl.com/" title="ASpiRE! Modeling Agency Website" target="_blank">ASpiRE! Modeling Agency</a>. In addition, I host a radio show called <a href="http://www.aspiresl.com/aspire_radio/radio_thevoice.php" title="ASpiRE! Radio - The Voice" target="_blank">"The Voice"</a> with CIO of ASpiRE!, Trina Noland every Thursday nights at 9 pm Eastern (6pm SL time) .  So now you have multiple ways to get in touch with me. If you find that you're having a hard time remembering to log off, I'll be more then happy to send you little reminders If I'm online. ;)]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Lessons on Faith - The Introduction</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/23/lessons-on-faith-the-introduction/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 23 Dec 2007 20:08:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/23/lessons-on-faith-the-introduction/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<h3>What authority do I have to share lessons on faith?</h3>
In case you're wondering what makes me an expert on faith, I ask you this: Don't we all have authority to share lessons that we're learning? I never made any claims to be a scholar or a guru. I'm just a woman who is seeking the truth and trying to understand the life she has been given. Along the way, I thought I'd share some golden nuggets that were passed on to me.
<h3>What led to these lessons on faith?</h3>
For many years, I always would get this feeling of magic around Christmas time. I never had any proof of any miracles ever happening around that time of the year, but this sense of wonder would aways overtake me. Then a few months before Christmas in 2005, August 26 to be exact, I would finally get a chance to see if Miracles do happen during that time of the year. That night, my mom walked into the ER thinking that she was having an asthma attack. She would later suffer a cardiac arrest due to Pulmonary Edema - water in the lungs caused by a failing heart.

I watched my mother die that night. I also watched the nurses resuscitate her. I remember thinking, "She is still alive because we are meant to learn about miracles." I wasted no time in praying for her to heal. My brothers and his church prayed for her also. To top it off, I had ministers from other churches praying and I hired energy healers to work their magic. For months we prayed and fasted. So what do you think happened?

It's now 2 days before Christmas in 2007, and I'm thinking about my mom at the nursing home. That day she walked into the ER was the last time I saw her walk or heard her talk. My mom has been in a minimal conscious/vegetative-like state since that night. Doctors say that the lack of oxygen to the brain for such an extended period of time caused a lot of brain damage. And even after all the prayers and healings, there has been no significant change.

So what's the deal? Why wasn't my mother instantly healed? Can or does miracles still happen today? Also, if they do happen, how do we produce miracles at will like Jesus or Paul did? How do we provide healing to people with physical conditions like my mom or amputees? These questions and more have racked my brain for the past 2 years. In the process of contemplating the answers, I've learned a lot along the way. My plan is to share my lessons with you in future posts and my prayer is that you are both challenged and inspired by them.

Before we continue, let me set the record straight. I don't consider myself a Christian. The reason why I don't consider myself a Christian is because I don't believe that Christianity, or any religion for that matter, hold the key to heaven. I won't go any further for now, because this topic alone is a whole article in itself.

In case you're wondering what my beliefs are,  I do believe in God and that Jesus is the Son of God. However, I also believe that the purpose of Jesus' teachings was to show us that we too are daughters and sons of God. I'll take that a step further and say that I believe that our purpose on this planet is to discover the truth about who we are. My theory is that the more we discover about ourselves, the more we become like Jesus. Like Jesus, we will one day be able to instantly heal the sick and raise the the dead. So why aren't we doing these things now? This question I also plan to address.

I will be posting Lesson 1 later on today, so stay tuned.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Why wait until Christmas?</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/24/why-wait-until-christmas/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Dec 2007 05:11:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/24/why-wait-until-christmas/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I was thinking about the holidays and how we tend to act differently towards each other around this time of the year. That thought process inspired me to create my very first Youtube video. I would love to hear your responses, so be sure to let me know what you think.  ;) ...
<pre>
<p align="center">

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Lesson 1: Real Faith versus Fake Faith</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/24/lesson-1-real-faith-versus-fake-faith/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Dec 2007 11:52:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/24/lesson-1-real-faith-versus-fake-faith/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the past 2 years since my mother got sick, I have seen 3 residents who shared a room with her pass away and one that was taken off life support. This made me wonder why there are so many psychics and faith healers claiming to do miracles, while many like these women waste away and die.  Not once in all this pondering did I see myself as someone who can make a difference in this area. I mean, I don't even consider myself a Christian anymore. Why would God or the Holy Spirit want to work through me?

Then one day, I got tired of hoping that someone would come along to do a miracle for my mom, so I picked a bible and started doing my own research. What I learned convicted the heck out of me. And nowhere did Jesus say that his teachings were limited only to people who have a "Christian" title. Maybe there was hope for me after all.

According to Webster, here are a few definitions for <strong>faith</strong>:
<blockquote>1 a: allegiance to duty or a person : loyalty b

(1): fidelity to one's promises
(2): sincerity of intentions

2 a (1): belief and trust in and loyalty to God (2): belief in the traditional doctrines of a religion
b (1): firm belief in something for which there is no proof (2): complete trust

3: something that is believed especially with strong conviction; especially : a system of religious beliefs</blockquote>
All of these definitions explain different aspects of what faith is, but from what I've read, neither seem to be enough to produce miracles, not even number 2. Now don't get me wrong, I do believe that believing and trusting in God is a necessary step. However, I  found that you have to take it a few steps further then this. In Mark 11:22-24, Jesus says:
<blockquote>22"Have[a] faith in God," Jesus answered.
23"I tell you the truth, if anyone says to this mountain, 'Go, throw yourself into the sea,' and does not doubt in his heart but believes that what he says will happen, it will be done for him.
24Therefore I tell you, whatever you ask for in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours. (NIV)</blockquote>
As you can see, one of the first things Jesus expects us to do is to have faith in God. However, he goes on to add 2 extra steps that we must take in order to produce miracles  like he did. He tells us:
<blockquote>1. We <strong>must not doubt</strong>  (vs. 23)

2. Whatever we ask for in prayer, we <strong>must believe we have received</strong> them in order to have them. (vs. 24)</blockquote>
When I really sat down and thought about what this passage is saying, it hit me like a ton of bricks. I'm sure many of us who've read that passage before, skimmed past it thinking that we fully understood what's being said here, but did we? Is it possible that the reason why the dead are not being raised and the amputees and coma patients are not being healed is because we don't have the faith that's being asked of us in this passage?

I mean let's be real, how many of us can see someone with an obvious ailment right this second, such as an amputee, and pray for them with <strong>absolutely no doubt</strong> in our minds? Let's take it a step further, how many of us can pray for that person and also believe that <strong>we have received</strong> what we ask for? Notice that I didn't say believe that <em>we will</em> receive, but that <em><strong>we have</strong></em> received - big difference.

Believing that <em>we will receive</em> means we live with the hope of maybe one day getting what we asked for. We live in a world of "see it to believe it". As much as this looks like real faith, it really isn't. It's the fake stuff, almost like a cheap imitation gold bracelet being passed for an18k bracelet. Looks similar, but just doesn't quite cut it. It's the type of belief system that says "although Jesus says that we will get what we ask for if we believe we have received it, he might be wrong. Let's not expect so much from God and instead hope that someday  God will answer our prayers,  if He feels like it."

On the other hand, believing that <em><strong>we have received</strong></em> means we are with God in the present. We live in a world of "believing in order to see." This is like a bracelet with the purest gold you can find. You can approach any appraiser with it and you know you will receive it's full worth. This is what I call real faith. With this type of faith, we trust in God and believe what Jesus said in verse 24. There is no room for doubt. We don't question whether or not it's God's will to answer our prayers. We know that God knows our motives (James 4:3) and considers this when answering our prayers. With this knowledge,  we simply check ourselves before approaching His throne. We walk away from our prayer knowing without a doubt, that we have what we asked for.

In <em>The Hidden Power of the Bible by Ernest Holmes, </em>he sums up everything that I am saying here in such a simple way. He writes:
<blockquote>If we lack wisdom, we are to come to the source of all knowledge and we shall receive it. But how are we to ask? In faith, believing! A double-minded man gets nowhere. How true this is! God can give us only what we can take, and since taking is a mental act, we can take only what we believe we already have. This is in accord with the teaching of Jesus, that when we pray we must believe we already have the answer to our prayers. <em>(page 197)</em></blockquote>
At this point you're probably wondering if I have attained this type of faith myself. Not yet. At least not in every area of my life. You see, my brain has been trained most of my life to see and then believe. Nonetheless, there is an area of my life that helps me to know that miracles do happen. I was born with a dislocated hip and had to endure 4 surgeries in attempt to fix it. After the last operation, the doctors saw it as an unsuccessful surgery and told my mother that I would not walk past the age of puberty. However, even as a young, impressionable child, I never accepted this diagnosis. For some reason that is beyond me, I still don't believe that what the doctor said held any truth to it. And today, thirty something years later, I am still walking. Now, if only I can have this kind of unwavering conviction in every areas of my life. In addition to this area of my life, God has shown me time and time again lately that when I make up my mind on about something, it literally manifests for me. I just need to learn to be consistent.

So yeah, purifying my faith is definitely on my to-do list. There are too many lives at stake for it not to be. If there are any of you reading this who have reached the point of having pure faith, I would love to hear and learn from you. For the rest of you, I pray that this lesson will encourage you to aim have the type of faith that "heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those who have leprosy, drive out demons" (Matthew 10: 8). I think the time is now for us to start doing the same things that Jesus was doing, if not better (John 14:12). What do you think?

Be safe and stay tuned for Lesson 2.

<a href="http://EzineArticles.com/" target="_new">
<img src="http://EzineArticles.com/featured/images/ea_featured_70_1.gif" alt="As Featured On Ezine Articles" border="0" />
</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Happy Holidays!</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/24/happy-holidays/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Dec 2007 15:39:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/24/happy-holidays/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ok, I've been up most of the night... I seem to really be getting into this whole blogging thing. I was about to put my mac to sleep, but then I got this sudden urge to create a lil greeting card for everyone. So, here it goes:
<p align="center">Click the image to view the full-size.</p>

	<item>
		<title>What are your 2008 New Years Resolutions?</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/27/what-are-your-new-years-resolutions/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Dec 2007 16:08:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/27/what-are-your-new-years-resolutions/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Tonight in <a href="http://www.secondlife.com/?u=0f7085f55f4e4ae1675d6ee9faffe78d" title="Second Life" target="_blank">Second Life</a>, me and Trina Noland are going to be hosting our weekly Radio Show on <a href="http://www.aspiresl.com/aspire_radio/radio_home.php" title="ASpiRE! Radio" target="_blank">ASpiRE! Radio</a> called "<a href="http://www.aspiresl.com/aspire_radio/radio_thevoice.php" title="ASpiRE! Radio - The Voice" target="_blank">The Voice</a>." This week's topic is "New Years Resolutions" and I have to admit, I've been avoiding making them.

Ok, ok... this is where I come clean. My track record with keeping my New Years Resolutions these past few years have been shoddy at best. I always seem to find some excuse or distraction for falling short of my goal. Some of those excuses sounded good, but is there ever a good reason to break a promise to yourself?

So, I've decided to try something different for 2008. Up until now, I rarely told people what my New Years Resolutions were, and if I did tell someone, it was a person that I knew wouldn't hold me accountable.  This year, I am going to post them right here for the whole world to see... or at least the 3 people that actually read my blog :P .

With that said, here are my 2008 New Years Resolutions:
<ol>
	<li> Lose 40 pounds</li>
	<li>Have a budget and stick to it</li>
	<li>Stay organized with all my paperwork  (e.g. mail, bills, etc.)</li>
	<li>Take better care of my fingernails and toenails
(they are looking pretty scary right now...)</li>
</ol>
Ok, that's it for now. I'll update this post if I think of any new goals. As for my weight loss, I have a plan in mind, which I will detail on my next post. Now that I've gone public with my goals for 2008, how about you? What are your New Years Resolutions?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Youtube Video 2: Christmas Collaboration Video</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/28/youtube-video-2-christmas-collaboration-video/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 28 Dec 2007 18:28:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/28/youtube-video-2-christmas-collaboration-video/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hey all, I just posted a new <a href="http://www.youtube.com/profile?user=natashasworld" title="Natasha's World Youtube Channel" target="_blank">Youtube</a> Video. Josh from Vlogeveryday asked people to submit movies for a Christmas Collaboration. At first, I thought to myself, "yeah right, I'm not going to make a fool of myself!" But after  I gave it some thought, I decided to go for it. Yes, I admit, my first concern was that people would leave mean comments. But you know what, whateva! I had fun making this video and that's all that matters ... right?

Anyways, without further delay, I present to you my response to Josh's Christmas Collaboration Video:
<pre>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What I would do if I had $100,000</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/29/what-i-would-do-if-i-had-100000/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 30 Dec 2007 02:12:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/29/what-i-would-do-if-i-had-100000/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm sure many of you reading this have had those moments where you sit down and think about where you are financially. Maybe that moment came for you while you were trying to pay for a meal with your debit card, and was told that it was declined. Or maybe you were balancing your checkbook and realized you had no balance.

Well, I had one of those moments yesterday. I was looking around my room at piles of laundry needing to be done. The reason why they were not done is because I've been afraid to touch my checking account. Why am I afraid, you ask? Oh, that's because I haven't been working since September and my accounts are looking pretty sad.

Now, something like this can do one of two things to a person. You can either get very depressed and start looking for the strongest liquor you can find. Or, you can see this as an opportunity to re-evaluate past mistakes, and think about what you would do differently, if given a second chance. I chose the latter. I'm a sucker for second chances.

I then did the math and  am embarrassed to admit that the total was a little over 60K.  Yea. But, if I prayed for only 60K, then I would be broke again once all my debt was paid. That just won't work. So after much thought, I came up with the figure $100,000.
<blockquote> <em>Now, before I continue, let me clarify a couple of things. My credit has been excellent until I stopped working. In addition, most of my debt, 85% of it to be exact, are student loans and my car note. Now if you're wondering why I stopped working, that's a whole other post in and of itself. Just know one thing, it was justified.
</em></blockquote>
Anyhow, once I knew that I wanted to be blessed with $100,000, I put together the following breakdown of how I would use it:
<ol>
	<li>~60K would go towards all my debt. This includes my student loans, car note and credit card.</li>
	<li>10K would be donated to charity. I'm currently a <a href="http://donate.wvus.org/OA_HTML/xxwvibeCZzpEntry.jsp?go=sponsor&amp;site=WVDONATIONS&amp;respid=22372&amp;language=US" title="World Vision. Become a Child Sponsor Today." target="_blank">World Vision</a> sponsor, so some of that money would go to them. I would also support <a href="http://www.hopeww.org/" title="Hope World Wide" target="_blank">Hope World Wide</a> and <a href="http://www.heifer.org/" title="Heifer International" target="_blank">Heifer International</a>. Once I attract more money into my life, I'll support more organizations.</li>
	<li>10K would go to my brother. In my home we're not mushy people, but I admit that I am really grateful for him. He has been super supportive since I stopped working, and he has given up a lot to be here for Mom (to learn more about my mom's condition, click <a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/23/lessons-on-faith-the-introduction/" title="Lesson on Faith: The Introduction" target="_blank">here</a>). In addition, he hasn't been able to get all the equipment he needs to pursue his dream, which is to make movies. So my hope would be that the 10K would give him the edge that he needs to get started.</li>
	<li>Finally, that leaves me with 20K.
<ol>
	<li>5K would would be placed in a some type of interest-yielding account (e.g. money market).</li>
	<li>~6700 would be used to buy a Macbook Pro (<a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/28/youtube-video-2-christmas-collaboration-video/" title="What Santa Didn't Give Me - Collaboration Video" target="_blank">which Santa did not bring me last Christmas</a>) and the Adobe Creative Suite Web Premium</li>
	<li>~1000-1600 would go towards a down payment for a new apartment (my lease ends in February and I have to move. No option to stay. Yea.)</li>
	<li> Anything left over would be split. Half would go to my checking and the other half would go to my savings. This would hold me over until I start my new job in January.</li>
	<li><strong>Maintenance:</strong> I would make a budget where I determine how much I spend on certain things each month.  For example, I would give myself an allowance to spend no more then $50 a week on eating out, etc. In this way, whatever is leftover at the end of the month would go into my savings.</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
Now I know, I can hear you now. Your probably thinking that I'm still not that well off after all is said and done. Heck, maybe you're even wondering why I don't pray for more. Well, $100,000 just makes sense to me. I believe that once I gets used to having money flow into my life, I will attract more.

So, there you have it. Now you know what I would do if I had $100,000. What about you? How would you spend it?

By the way, if after reading this, you're feeling a bit generous or motivated to give, I am willing to accept your tax write-off as a donation. Simply click <a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_xclick&amp;business=webqueen%40natashasworld%2ecom&amp;item_name=Donation%20to%20Natasha&amp;no_shipping=1&amp;return=http%3a%2f%2fnatashasworld%2ecom%2fjournal%2fthank%2dyou%2dfor%2dyour%2ddonation%2f&amp;tax=0&amp;currency_code=USD&amp;lc=US&amp;bn=PP%2dDonationsBF&amp;charset=UTF%2d8" title="Donation to Natasha" target="_blank">here</a> and we can get the ball rolling. Happy New Year! :D]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Natasha Pierre-Louis for President  - Election 2008</title>

	<item>
		<title>September 11, 2001 and Zeitgeist</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=86</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=86</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[To start off, my heart goes out to all the families who lost a loved one on September 11, 2001. I'd like to take a moment of Silence.

...

...

...

It's crazy how 7 years later I still remember September 11, 2001 like it was yesterday. At that time I was attending FAU in Davie, FL. I remember just getting out of class and walking out of the Arts and Sciences building towards the BCC Library. There was a serious buzz in the air and students either had a stunned look on their face or panic as they made calls on their cells. I turned to someone standing next to me and asked, "What's going on?" "Two planes just crashed into the World Trade Center, " she replied. At that moment it felt like time stood still.

Seconds later reality came rushing back and I thought, "Oh God, my aunt..." I dialed her number and all I kept getting was a busy signal. It seemed like everyone from everywhere was calling New York at the same time... I freaked out because I had no idea what to think. Just when I thought I was about to snap, I was able to get in touch with her and she was ok.

Just thinking about that day brings me right back to that moment. My uncle, who is a medical examiner in NY, worked for months on Ground Zero. In his whole career, he said he never experienced anything like it before or since.

And all of these thoughts float around in my head as I contemplate a movie I saw recently called <a title="Zeitgeist - The Movie" href="http://www.zeitgeistmovie.com/" target="_blank">Zeitgeist</a>. Someone sent the link to me and all I can say is wow. It's one of those movies that after you watch it you feel like Morpheus from <a title="What is the Matrix" href="http://whatisthematrix.warnerbros.com/" target="_blank">The Matrix</a> just gave you the red pill. If you have 2 hours to spare and an open mind,  then pull up a chair and some popcorn, and prepare for a crazy ride.

To be fair, here are a couple of sites talk abo]]></content:encoded>

		<title>test</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=88</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=88</guid>
		<description></description>

	<item>
		<title>This is a test</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=90</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Sep 2008 18:17:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/09/28/this-is-a-test/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://slurl.com/secondlife/DIXON%20Feever/46/162/48/">DIXON Feever 46,162,48</a> - note this is only a test]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>90</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2008-09-28 14:17:54]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2008-09-28 18:17:54]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[this-is-a-test]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[draft]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[ratings_users]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[ratings_score]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[ratings_average]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>

		<title>Yes we Can, Yes we Did!</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=120</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[November 4, 2008 will be a day I will always cherish. I am grateful that in my lifetime I was able to witness the first African American be elected as the 44th President of the Unites States of America. This is a true sign that this county is changing and progressing. I felt so proud as I watched President Obama give his victory speech, almost like a mother watching her son.

Yesterday was also special because I recieved my Gohonzon.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>In the Beginning - Day 1 of Master Cleanse</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/?p=174</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Mar 2009 14:59:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2009/03/12/in-the-beginning-day-1-of-master-cleanse/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After many stumbling blocks, I have finally started Round 2 of the Master Cleanse. I still love the lemon drink itself, but the salt flush was tough. At one point I thought I was going to gag. I am determined to find a way to make the flush an easier process. After the flush, I was supposed to feel this "sudden urge" after 30 minutes to an hour but nah, for my body that would be way to easy. It wouldn't be until after I reached the office that it decided to kick in. I can already tell that this round is going to be a heck of a ride...]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>174</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>New Years Greeting &amp; Changes to this Site</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/31/new-years-greeting-changes-to-this-site/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 31 Dec 2007 21:25:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2007/12/31/new-years-greeting-changes-to-this-site/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Let me start by saying, "Happy New Years Everybody! May 2008 bring you much joy, blessings and laughter."

Now on to the changes. I'm constantly thinking of how I can improve the flow of this site and the user/reader experience. For that reason, I've made the following  updates:
<ol>
	<li>I removed the long colorful buttons that once lived beneath the subscription form. I replaced them with cuter and smaller square buttons.</li>
	<li>I enhanced this site with Snap Shot. Just in case you're not familiar with it, Snap Shot enhances links with a visual preview of the destination site. In this way, you get a sneak peek to where a link will lead, without having to leave the site. Here's an example:
<a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/snapshot_ex.jpg" title="Snap Shot example"><img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/snapshot_ex.jpg" alt="Snap Shot example" border="0" />
</a>
If you should decide that you're not into this Snap Shot feature, just click on the Options icon and select "Disable". Cool huh?</li>
	<li>Last, I removed the the 125x125 ads, in exception for the <a href="http://donate.wvus.org/OA_HTML/xxwvibeCZzpEntry.jsp?go=sponsor&amp;site=WVDONATIONS&amp;respid=22372&amp;language=US" title="World Vision" target="_blank">World Vision</a> and <a href="http://www.secondlife.com?u=0f7085f55f4e4ae1675d6ee9faffe78d" title="Second Life" target="_blank">Second Life</a> banners. I've decided that I'm going to create a Links Page, where I'll list cool resources, quality products and services that I believe are worth promoting.</li>
</ol>
Well, that's all for now. As I make more changes, I'll post about them so that you won't be confused when you stop by. If you have any suggestions, please feel free to drop me a <a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/contact-natasha/" title="Send me an email">note</a>. Be safe tonight and party responsibly. ;)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Free Marketing Tools &amp; Articles for New Bloggers</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/01/04/free-marketing-tools-articles-for-new-bloggers/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Jan 2008 11:19:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/01/04/free-marketing-tools-articles-for-new-bloggers/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I am so psyched by the wealth of free information I'm finding online on how to build a successful blog. This must be a newbie blogger reaction, because I feel like a kid in the candy store. Here are a few freebies that I think will excite you as well:
<h3><a href="http://www.mikes-marketing-tools.com/ranking-reports/" title="Free Search Engine Ranking Tool" target="_blank">Free Search Engine Ranking Tool</a></h3>
Have you ever wondered how your page ranks for certain keywords in the major search engines and directories? Well, Mike's Free Search Engine Ranking tool tells you just that. Simply enter your URL and keywords, and it tells you if you're in the top 50 listings in <a href="http://www.google.com/" title="Google" target="_blank">Google</a>, <a href="http://search.yahoo.com/" title="Yahoo! Search" target="_blank">Yahoo! Search</a>,<a href="http://search.aol.com/" title="AOL Search" target="_blank"> AOL</a>, <a href="http://www.msn.com/" title="MSN" target="_blank">MSN</a>, <a href="http://www.alltheweb.com/" title="AllTheWeb" target="_blank">AllTheWeb</a>, <a href="http://www.altavista.com/" title="Altavista" target="_blank">Altavista</a>, <a href="http://dir.yahoo.com/" title="Yahoo! Directory" target="_blank">Yahoo! Directory</a> and <a href="http://www.dmoz.org/" title="Open Directory">Open Directory</a>. Also, be sure to check out some of his other free tools.
<h3>Article: <a href="http://www.problogger.net/archives/2007/01/11/how-to-market-your-blog-in-2007/" title="How to Market your Blog in 2007" target="_blank">How to Market your Blog in 2007</a></h3>
This post was written by Tony Hung who was a guess blogger on <a href="http://www.problogger.net/" title="Problogger.net" target="_blank">Problogger.net</a>. Although it was written for 2007, it is still a treasure chest full of golden nuggets and gems. From my count, he listed about 41 ways to market your blog. To a newbie blogger like me, it's as if he took my hand and said, "Come, let me show you..." I also found this other article on <a href="http://www.problogger.net/archives/2006/03/22/optimizing-your-title-tag-for-seo-on-3-different-platforms/" title="Optimizing your Titke Tag for SEO" target="_blank">optimizing your title tag</a> very informative and helpful. So come to think of it, the entire Problogger website is a treasure trove full of useful blog tips to help people make money online.
<h3>Article: <a href="http://chrisbrogan.com/some-tips-to-fine-tune-your-blog-for-2008/" title="Some Tips to Fine Tune Your Blog for 2008" target="_blank">Some Tips to Fine Tune Your Blog for 2008</a></h3>
For an up to date way to improve your blog, I also recommend this article. Chris Brogan list many ways to make your blog rock. Some of his suggestion seem basic, but are often missed by us newbs. For example, he mentions that simply writing good titles can  play a huge role in bringing new visitors. Content is also important, but if your titles aren't catchy or google-friendly, they will get ignored. He also suggest many cool free tools, such as the Web Site Grader, which I'll talk more about next. Definitely an article worth checking out.
<h3><a href="http://www.websitegrader.com/" title="Web Site Grader" target="_blank">Web Site Grader</a></h3>
This tool does just what it says, it grades your site. I tested it out and was impressed by how much information it gave in regards to the marketing effectiveness of my blog. I realized after getting graded that I  still have much work to do, but as quoted from GI Joe, "knowing is half the battle".
<h3>Article: <a href="http://www.pureblogic.com/Make-It-Easier-To-Generate-Daily-Content-For-Your-Blog" title="Make it Easier to Generate Daily Content for your Blog">Make it Easier to Generate Daily Content for your Blog</a><a href="http://www.pureblogic.com/make-it-easier-to-generate-daily-content-for-your-blog/" title="Make it Easier to Generate Daily Content for your Blog" target="_blank">  </a></h3>
In this article, Kila gives some great tips on how to generate daily content for your blog. These tips are simple, but very important. If implemented, they can prevent a new blogger from getting burnt out and quitting.

And these marketing tools and articles are just a handful of the information that you can find online. If you know of any that you think are worth mentioning, I'd love to hear about it.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Barbara]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email><![CDATA[barbara@bloggingwithoutablog.com]]></wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://bloggingwithoutablog.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP><![CDATA[216.228.175.26]]></wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date><![CDATA[2008-01-21 04:36:00]]></wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt><![CDATA[2008-01-21 09:36:00]]></wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hi Natasha,

I have been blogging for nearly a year now.  One of my blogs is about blogging, and I share what I have learned, with others.  

My post for today, is about new bloggers.  I have challenged my existing readers to seek out, and reach out to new bloggers, (after all, we were all new, at one time or another).  

Anyway, I will search for a new blog each week, and provide a link in one of my daily posts, to that blog.....hopefully gaining more exposure for the new blogger, and giving them moral support, to keep blogging. 

I found your blog by doing a search for "newbie blogger", then proceeding to page 11 of the search results.  

You have the beginnings of what looks to be a great blog.  You write from your heart, and openly share.  To me, that's a winning combination.  

Just so you know, later this week, I will provide a link to your blog in one of my posts.  My hope is, that by doing so, I can send a little bit of traffic your way, and motivate you to continue on with this great blog.  

See you in blogosphere!  :D

<em>Barbara's last blog post..<a href='http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/bloggingwithoutablog/DWWZ/~3/220247451/' rel="nofollow">New Blogger Begins To Feel Like An Abandoned Dog</a></em>]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>A Letter to My Mom</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/01/12/a-letter-to-my-mom/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 12 Jan 2008 18:15:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/01/12/a-letter-to-my-mom/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After watching <a href="http://youtube.com/watch?v=s2HPk_MckAg" title="Jia's Tag of Luv" target="_blank">Jia's Tag of Luv</a>, I was inspired to create this one, dedicated to my mom.
<pre>
<object height="355" width="425">
<param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/gSnez-i4ZY8&amp;rel=1"></param>
<param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/gSnez-i4ZY8&amp;rel=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" height="355" width="425"></embed></object></pre>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>33</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2008-01-12 13:15:01]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2008-01-12 18:15:01]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[a-letter-to-my-mom]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

<em>Emma's last blog post..<a href='http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ItsWriteNow/~3/218418673/' rel="nofollow">Finally Triple Digits!</a></em>]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Weight Loss Challenge for 2008</title>
		<link>http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/01/19/weight-loss-challenge-for-2008/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Jan 2008 20:30:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[natashapl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://natashasworld.com/journal/2008/01/19/weight-loss-challenge-for-2008/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A few years ago, I was shopping for books and stumbled upon one called "<a href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0812931416?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=natashaswor04-20&amp;linkCode=xm2&amp;camp=1789&amp;creativeASIN=0812931416" title="Be a Loser by Greer Childers" target="_blank">Be a Loser</a>" by Greer Childers. It introduced me to aerobic breathing, a technique that allows oxygen to quickly flood your body. The premise behind it is that oxygen burns fat and by breathing in so much of it, your body will lose fat. The book was very informative, but Greer's method was a bit challenging for me. I started looking around for alternatives and found Rashelle Haines' <a href="http://www.lifelift.net/cgi-bin/affiliates/clickthru.cgi?id=natashapl" title="Life Lift" target="_blank">Life Lift video</a>.  Rashelle's approach is very gentle and she is very soothing to listen to.

Unfortunately, I never stuck to it long enough to see results. I sorta got discouraged because years ago there were no before and after pictures from other users. However, a few days ago I decided to revisit Rashelle's site and was blown away by <a href="http://www.oxygenlift.net/lifelift_testimonials" title="Steffi Power's Life Lift Testimonial">Steffi Power's testimonial</a>.  This woman went from 190 pounds to her current weight of 130 pounds. Her routine was to do her aerobic breathing exercises, drink plenty of water and not skip any meals. A bit challenging for some of us with bad habits, but very simple and doable.

So, I am on a mission. One of my New Years Resolutions for 2008 is to lose 40 pounds and I believe that <a href="http://www.lifelift.net/cgi-bin/affiliates/clickthru.cgi?id=natashapl" title="Aerobic breathing" target="_blank">aerobic breathing</a> may be the method for me. In case you're wondering, I have tried more traditional methods. I've done the changes in diet, typical workout and even lifted weights. My problem is that I don't do well with too much restrictions. Whenever I hear "You should or should not do that.." I want to do the opposite. And so you can imagine how challenging it was for me to try and follow a weight loss plan.

The difference with this is that I don't feel restricted. I don't have to stop eating my favorite foods and there are no memberships to joins or pills to take. I simply have to:
<ol>
	<li>Make a small commitment to do my breaths everyday</li>
	<li>Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water</li>
	<li>Eat when I'm hungry</li>
</ol>
I already started doing aerobic breathing exercises on Wednesday morning. I also measured and weighed myself.

Here are my stats and future plans:
<a href="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2008/01/before_1_19_08.jpg" title="Natasha’s Before Picture"><img src="http://natashasworld.com/journal/wp-content/uploads/2008/01/before_1_19_08.jpg" alt="Natasha’s Before Picture" class="img_floatL" border="0" height="305" width="150" /></a>

<strong>Stats:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Weight:         197 lbs.</li>
	<li>Chest:          42.5"</li>
	<li>Waist:          35.5"</li>
	<li>Hip:            46"</li>
	<li>Left Bicep:     12.25"</li>
	<li>Left Thigh:     27.25"</li>
</ul>
<strong>Plans:</strong>
<ol>
	<li> I intend to post videos with more details on how aerobic breathing works and what my routine is going to be.</li>
	<li>I will be weighing in and posting the results every week.</li>
	<li>Once a month I intend to post updated "after" photos. If I see a dramatic result sooner, I'll post the picture at that time regardless of the time span.</li>
</ol>
I am both excited and nervous at the same time. I'm tired of feeling heavy, so the possibility of finally losing this weight gets me fired up! At the same time, I am revealing my size and weight to the world which is kinda scary to me. Will people judge me for weighing as much as I do? Will I be disciplined enough to stick to my goals? These questions and more are running through my mind as I type this.

Ah well, I'm going forward anyways. I believe this is a year of change - does that make me sound like a politician? Anyhow, stay tuned.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hiya natasha... Should get one of those chat boxes :)

Anyways, good luck for your weight loss challenge.   Another one tip tasha, visualization. See yourself with the weight that you want to have. Find pictures of slim people to help you with the visualization if you like.

<em>syari's last blog post..<a href='http://painz-celebratinglife.blogspot.com/2008/01/hungarian-famous-graffitis.html' rel="nofollow">Hungarian famous graffitis.</a></em>]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved><![CDATA[1]]></wp:comment_approved>

		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>105</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Zenobia]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email><![CDATA[theperennialgarden@gmail.com]]></wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.theperennialgarden.blogspot.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP><![CDATA[167.127.163.141]]></wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date><![CDATA[2008-01-21 13:49:22]]></wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt><![CDATA[2008-01-21 18:49:22]]></wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I'd just like to add a little comment to Natasha, myself and anyone else accepting this challenge.  This is not about taking a journey to "create" a new you; but it is a journey to "enhance" you.  To often, we get caught up in the media hype and have allowed it to dictate what we should or should not look like.  As a result, we spend too much time and energy condemning ourselves for not meeting the "standards" that they have set.  

If you dont' mind, I'd like to add to the challenge that has been issued.  I challenge anyone taking this walk with Natasha to remove the blinders that they have been handed by society and see the God-given beauty that you already possess.  In doing so, you may find that your goal will seem less stressful and much more achievable.  Accept this challenge with the idea of obtaining the best "you" as opposed to the best "them".

Ladies (and gents) work what you got and LOVE what you got.  If you want (or need for health reasons) to make improvements along the way, so be it.  Just do so with the right heart and attitude.  Because, until we do, we will never be satisfied and will always find flaws.  We are already beautiful....embrace it!

With much respect,

Z

<em>Zenobia's last blog post..<a href='http://theperennialgarden.blogspot.com/2008/01/appraising-your-home.html' rel="nofollow">Appraising Your Home</a></em>]]></wp:comment_content>
